Our @ClimateCrisis Action Plan will help enhance the ecological benefits, biodiversity, and carbon sequestration value of natural ecosystems and our most treasured wild places. Learn more on my website at https://bonamici.house.gov/ClimateActionPlan. #OregonClimateAction

Our Climate Action Plan improves research and monitoring of ocean acidification, harmful algal blooms, & hypoxia, which are becoming seasonal issues in NW Oregon. Our plan includes my COAST Research Act, which passed the House last June, and three other bills I co-led. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EewSkynXYAEo1rk.jpg

According to @oceanpanel, blue carbon ecosystems like seagrasses and mangroves, could prevent approximately one gigaton of carbon dioxide from entering the atmosphere by 2050. My bipartisan Blue Carbon for Our Planet Act included in our plan will help conserve these ecosystems.

Every person on this planet benefits from a healthy ocean. As Co-Chair of the House Oceans Caucus & Congressional Estuary Caucus, I'm thrilled that #OceanClimateAction is at the core of our plan for #SolvingTheClimateCrisis.

Environmental justice communities often experience inequitable access to green spaces and outdoor recreation. Our Climate Action Plan includes a new commission to formally & meaningfully consult and better support the conservation priorities and vision of Tribal Nations.

Our plan for #SolvingTheClimateCrisis will improve federal forest management, restore natural fire regimes, develop region-specific climate-smart forestry plans, and scale up the use of sustainably harvested mass timber. These policies will support our rural timber economies.

Our Climate Action Plan:

üåéprotects at least 30% of our lands and ocean no later than 2030

üåÑprovides full and permanent funding for the #LWCF to protect our wild places

üèûÔ∏èsets a goal of net-zero emissions on public lands and waters by 2040 & prohibits offshore drilling

The most recent stop on my #OregonClimateAction tour was a virtual roundtable with scientists and experts on ocean, estuary, and forestry issues. In typical August fashion, some Oregonians called in directly from the field where they were actively advancing their research. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EewQ8PWXsAAT1-M.png

Our ocean, public lands, & forests sequester and store carbon dioxide, provide important habitat for wildlife, and make our ecosystems & communities more resilient. Our plan for #SolvingTheClimateCrisis embraces the mitigation potential of natural climate solutions. üå≤üåäüèîÔ∏è

Ending New START and the limits it imposes is no way to advance nonproliferation. As we reflect on the destruction we saw 75 years ago, the global community must recommit to reducing the number of nuclear weapons in the world. We can begin by extending New START.

Our last remaining bilateral nuclear arms deal with Russia, New START, is set to expire in February. But a clause in the treaty allows for an automatic five-year extension while a successor agreement is negotiated. I‚Äôm calling on President Trump to invoke this clause immediately.

Today is the 75th anniversary of the atomic bomb being dropped on Hiroshima during World War II. Now more than ever, this anniversary should be a reminder of the need to prevent the proliferation of nuclear weapons.

Instead of joining us, too many Republicans have worked to undermine voting rights & increase barriers to the ballot box for historically disenfranchised voters. (6/7)

In New Mexico, we‚Äôve taken the opposite path ‚Äî expanding same-day voter registration and automatic voter registration to make it easier for people to cast their ballot.

Here's the bottom line: Elections matter. (5/7)

When the VRA passed, civil rights advocates knew the fight wasn‚Äôt over. For decades after, Congress and the courts agreed with them & the VRA was expanded 5 times to increase its protections.

But in recent years, the Supreme Court has turned back the clock on civil rights. (2/7)

After he was liberated, Henry returned home to Arizona to build a family, serving as a Sunday school teacher and deacon at his church and working as a real estate and insurance broker. We're grateful for his lifetime of service to Arizona and our country. Godspeed, Henry.

On his last flight before returning home, Henry‚Äôs plane was shot down and he was captured as a prisoner of war by the Nazis. He spent nearly nine months as a prisoner, and as the Nazis began liquidating the camps, he was forced to march over 1,000 miles during the brutal winter.

After graduating from Phoenix Union High School, Henry and his three brothers joined the U.S. Army to fight in World War II. Henry and his crew flew 29 successful bombing missions in Europe, including being part of the D-Day invasion on the beaches of Normandy.

Henry Ong, Jr. was an American hero of the Greatest Generation, and a valued member of our community. Henry passed away this summer, and I was honored to enter a tribute to his remarkable life into the Congressional Record and present it to his family.
